title: 'Outrageous': Judge slams ACCC over VW deal
text:
The statement said the Volkswagen board did not know of the alleged cheating, which would mean its directors would be shielded from charges or penalties.

Justice Foster said he would base the penalty he imposed off that position, but that the fact it could be true "beggars belief".

"Doesn't that mean that the corporate governance of this very large corporation was hopeless, because this decision to build these engines in the way they did is a massive enterprise in itself?" he said.

"Doesn’t that mean that they just had no idea what was going on in the company? Why isn’t that a massive negative for Volkswagen in terms of its corporate governance?

“Someone had to know about it. Someone had to write the cheques or pass it through the electronic banking system."

When Jeremy Kirk, SC, appearing for the ACCC, told him that settlements needed compromise, the judge fired back "you don't have to agree with things that are completely wrong".

He also said it was unclear why the settlement penalty needed to be "far less" than the ACCC would have got had they won at trial.

While settlements from regulators require court approval, judges do not usually overrule agreed penalties. Justice Foster said the penalty was up to him to decide, however.

Advertisement

Looking abroad

The cheating allegations put forward by the ACCC were mirrored in civil and criminal actions overseas and VW tried to convince Justice Foster that penalties imposed abroad should be considered in any Australian fine.

A US Federal Court judge hit Volkswagen with a $US2.8 billion ($4.1 billion) criminal fine in 2017 after finding the automaker rigged emissions testing to cheat government emissions testing.

This brought the total penalties paid by Volkswagen in the US to over $US25 billion, as it had already been ordered to pay compensation to drivers among other fines.

Volkswagen was also hit with a €1 billion ($1.61 billion) fine in Germany and one of its executives, Oliver Schmidt, copped a $US400,000 penalty in the US and a seven-year jail sentence.

"The financial pain or consequences of the underlying wrongdoing that led to these contraventions has already been subject to financial penalty elsewhere ... we ask Your Honour to consider that," Garry Rich, SC, said for Volkswagen.

Justice Foster responded by accusing him of only providing selective information about other fines.

"Am I being told that the US fines and these [Australian] fines are the only ones in the world being imposed? Are these selectively chosen, am I just being given select press releases?" he asked.

Advertisement

"What am I supposed to make of this, that this is just another fine? There's going to be a lot of them.

He accepted the ACCC's case that fines abroad should not be considered, but then threw that back in Mr Kirk's face when the barrister tried to argue that the "unprecedented" $75 million penalty was appropriate as it far exceeded previous ACCC fines.

"That doesn’t matter. You've spent some time telling me I shouldn't be influenced by other countries and cases and I agree with that. This is so out there on its own in terms of scale, impact, deliberateness [that] I don’t really think pointing me to any other case is going to help me."

Audi goes under ACCC's radar

The initial charges brought by the ACCC, as well as cases abroad and domestic class actions, also named Audi as party to 'dieselgate'.

But the ACCC and Volkswagen settlement made no mention of them, which Justice Foster was quick to criticise.

"It would be the submission of the parties that I could not ... take into account the Audi vehicles affected by this penalty at all," he said.

"Yes," Mr Kirk responded.

Advertisement

"I'm nonetheless entitled to comment on them ... just not take it into account in the penalty," the judge warned.

Mr Kirk admitted the Audi cars were "wrapped up in some scandal" but suggested the ACCC needed to prioritise its attention to Volkswagen.

The class action brought against Volkswagen and Audi domestically settled for settled last month for $87-127 million and no admission of guilt from the automakers.
description: A Federal Court judge has thrashed the watchdog for going too easy on Volkswagen for cheating emissions testing, saying Australians would be "very upset".
